p: Despite the tremendous efforts invested in Flavivirus research, no clinically approved antiviral chemotherapeutics are available for humans, and disease treatment is limited to supportive care [ 13]. Inhibition of viral enzymes has proved to be one important approach toward the development of antiviral therapies [ 2, 13â€“ 15]. Non-structural proteins encoded by these RNA viruses are essential for their replication and maturation, and thus may offer ideal targets for developing antiviral drugs [ 2]. Flavivirus genomes are translated into a single polyprotein that needs to be cleaved by viral and host proteases. Because it processes most of the polyprotein cleavages, viral protease is necessary and essential for virus replication [ 16, 17].
